item.label: tramp
item.gloss: one who travels from place to place on foot, in search of employment, or as a vagrant (tramp, n.1, 4a)

item.label: dogies
item.gloss: Originally: an unacclimatized young heifer or steer on a range. Subsequently: a neglected or undernourished calf, esp. one without a mother (dogie, n)

A scrubby calf that has not wintered well and is anemic from the scant food of the cold months. Adams' recounts the origin of the term:
Although the word os used commonly in the West and is understood by all cattlemen, there has been some controversy over its origin. One version is that during trail days, when it was discovered that the northern range was good cow country, especially for fattening beef, there arose a demand for young animals. Another, more likely, version is that the term originated in the eighties after a very severe winter had killed off a number of orphen calves. The bellies of the survivors very much resembled a batch of sour dough carried in a sac. During the roundup all orphan calves became known as dough-guts; later the term was shortened to dogie. 96–97

item.label: hummock
item.gloss: A protuberance or boss of earth, rock, etc., usually conical or dome-shaped, rising above the general level of a surface; a low hillock or knoll (hummock, n, 1)

item.label: coulie
item.gloss: A trench or other depression in the earth. Also: coulee.
A deep ravine or gulch scooped out by heavy rain or melting snow, but dry in summer (coulée, n, 2)

item.label: plug
item.gloss: A cake or stick of tobacco; a piece of this, esp. for chewing (plug, n, II.6)

item.label: roan
item.gloss: A horse with more or less uniformed mixture of white and colored hairs over the entire body (253)

item.label: Indian
item.gloss: Now understood primarily as a slur, Indian refers to Indigenous people of what is now North America, particularly, but not exclusively, Indigenous peoples of plains and the midwest. It was, and continues to be, the legal term for Indigenous people in Canada.

item.label: dime novel
item.gloss: A small, inexpensive paperback novel. Broadly, the term refers to books that contains little to no literary merit.
